column6: Footnotes

when the earth•when the earth … : Gen. 1 describes God’s bringing order out of chaos, not creation from nothingness. was Confusion and Chaos,
darkness over the face of Ocean,
•Ocean: The primeval waters, a common (and usually divine) image in ancient Near Eastern mythology, rushing-spirit•rushing-spirit: Others, “wind.” The Hebrew word ruah can mean both “spirit” and “wind.” See Ps. 33:6. of God hovering•hovering: Or “flitting.” The image suggested by the word (see Deut. 32:11) is that of an eagle protecting its young. over the face of the waters—

God called the dome: The Heavens.
There was setting, there was dawning: second day.

no bush of the field was yet on earth,
no plant of the field had yet sprung up,
for YHWH God had not made it rain upon the earth,
and there was no human/adam to work the ground/adama—

The human knew•knew: Intimately; a term for sexual intercourse. Havva his wife;
she became pregnant and bore Kayin.
•Kayin: Trad. English “Cain.” The name means “smith” (see also v.22, below). She said:
Kaniti/I-have-gotten
•I-have-gotten: Others use “I have created.” a man, along with YHWH!

that the divine ones saw how fair the human women were,
so they took themselves wives, whomever they chose.

For in another seven days
I will make it rain upon the earth for forty•forty: Used in the Bible to denote long periods of time; also a favorite patterned number. days and forty nights
and will blot out all existing-things that I have made, from the face of the earth.

In the six hundredth year of Noah’s life, in the second month, on the seventeenth day of the month,
on that day:
then burst•then burst …: Cassuto (1972) suggests that the poetic verses here and elsewhere in the Flood story are fragments of an Israelite epic. See also 9:11, 15. all the wellsprings of the great Ocean
and the sluices•well-springs … sluices: The normal sources of rain function here without any restraint (Cassuto). of the heavens opened up.

And those that came, male and female from all flesh they came,
as God had commanded him.
YHWH closed [the door] upon him.

all that had the breath of the rush of life in their nostrils,
all that were on dry-land, died.

And so it was in the six hundred and first year, in the beginning-month, on the first day of the month,
that the waters left dry-land upon the earth.
Noah removed the covering of the ark and saw:
here, the face of the ground had dried up.

Noah built a sacrificial-altar to YHWH.
He took from all pure animals and from all pure birds
and offered up•offered up: The Hebrew verb (’alo) implies upward movement. offerings on the altar.
Now Cush begot Nimrod; he was the first mighty-one on earth.
Canaan begot Tzidon his firstborn and Het,
And Avram was exceedingly heavily-laden with livestock, with silver and with gold.

But he•But he said: Avram, having just demonstrated trust in v.6, now expresses deep doubt, said:
My Lord YHWH,
by what shall I know that I will possess it?
and the Amorite and the Canaanite and the Girgashite and the Yevusite.

Now Sarai, Avram’s wife, had not borne him [children].
She had an Egyptian maid—her name was Hagar.
But <small>YHWH’S</small> messenger found her by a spring of water in the wilderness, by the spring on the way to Shur.

And as for Yishmael, I hearken to you:
here, I will make him•make him blessed … make him bear fruit … make him many: Heb. berakhti oto ve-hifreiti oto vehirbeiti oto. blessed, I will make him bear fruit, I will make him exceedingly, exceedingly many—
he will beget twelve exalted-leaders, and I will make a great nation of him.

Now it was, when the power-of-God caused me to roam•roam: A word which in Genesis suggests a wandering that is nevertheless directed by God. See 21:14 and 37:15 for other examples. This passage gives us a fascinating glimpse of Avraham’s own perception of the events in Chap. 12. It is not unusual for the biblical storyteller to give out informa-tion in this manner (in a later speech of the protagonist), from my father’s house,
that I said to her:
Let this be the favor that you do me:
in every place that we come, say of me: He is my brother.

And Avraham stretched out his hand,
he took the knife to slaughter his son.

and said:
By myself I swear
—YHWH’S utterance—
indeed, because you have done this thing, have not withheld your son, your only one,

He had the camels kneel outside the town at the water well
at sunset, at the time when the water-drawers•water-drawers: Female. go out,

These are the sons of Yishmael, these their names, in their farmsteads and in their corrals,
•corrals: Others (including Buber) use “circled encampments.” twelve leaders for their tribes.

Yitzhak was forty years old•forty years old: Another schematic number. Twenty years later (see v.26), his wife will bear him children. when he took Rivka daughter of Betuel the Aramean,•Aramean: Three times in this verse the root ‘Aram” confirms what we learned in the previous chapter—the importance of family and lineage here, from Paddan Aram, sister of Lavan the Aramean, for himself as a wife.

and make me a tasty-dish, such as I love;
bring it to me, and I will eat it,
that I may give you my own blessing•my own blessing: Or “my special blessing.” Heb. nefesh frequently means “self” or “personality.” before I die.

column3: Let your curse be on me
column6:
His mother said to him:
On me be your curse, my son!
Only: listen to my voice and go, take them for me.
and stay with him for some time, until your brother’s fury has turned away,

column3: arise go to the country of Aram
column6:
Arise, go to Paddan Aram, to the house of Betuel, your mother’s father,
and take yourself a wife from there, from the daughters of Lavan, your mother’s brother.

And he dreamt:
here,•Here: The word (three times) emphasizes the immediacy of the report; it is the vocabulary of dreams, as in 37:7 (Andersen). a stairway was set up on the earth,
its top reaching the heavens,
and here, messengers of God were going up and down on it.

Lavan said to him:
Without doubt you are my bone, my flesh!
And he stayed with him the days of a month.
Now Lavan had two daughters: the name of the elder was Le’a, the name of the younger was Rahel.

Now Yaakov stole the wits of Lavan the Aramean,
by not telling him that he was about to flee.

But God came to Lavan the Aramean in a dream of the night
and said to him:
Take you care,
lest you speak to Yaakov, good or ill!

Esav said:
Pray let me leave with you•leave with you: Or “station with you,” “put at your disposal.” some of the people who are mine.
•mine: Lit. “with me.” But he said:
Why, now?
May I only find favor in my lord’s eyes!

And he acquired•he acquired: Like his grandfather Avraham, Yaakov must purchase the land. the piece of territory where he had spread out his tent, from the Sons of Hamor, Shekhem’s father, for a hundred kesitas.

And Shekhem son of Hamor•Hamor: Heb. “donkey.” Some take the name to prove that they were donkey-drivers, while others see it as an insult to the character. the Hivvite, the prince of the land, saw her;
he took her and lay with her: he forced her.

and the young man did not hesitate to do the thing,
for he took delight in Yaakov’s daughter.
Now he carried more weight•carried more weight: I.e., was more respected. than anyone in his father’s house.

then Yitzhak expired.
He died and was gathered to his kinspeople, old and satisfied in days.
Esav and Yaakov his sons buried him.

His brothers envied him,
while his father kept the matter in mind.

He recognized it
and said:
My son’s•My son’s coat: With the omission of “It is,” the shock is conveyed more dramatically. Some ancient versions, however, include the phrase. tunic!
An ill-tempered beast has devoured him!
Yosef is ripped, ripped-to-pieces!

column3: fair of form and fair to look at
column4: beautiful of form and beautiful of appearance
column6:
So he left•left: Consigned; see also v.13 for a play on words. everything that was his in Yosef’s hands,
and did not not concern himself about anything with him there except for the bread that he•except for the bread that he ate: Since the Egyptians did not eat with foreigners (see, for instance, 43:32). ate.
Now Yosef was beautiful of form and beautiful of appearance.

he had him mount the chariot of his second-in-rank, and they called out before him: Avrekh!/Attention!
Thus he placed him over all the land of Egypt.

But he turned away from them and wept.
Then he returned to them; he spoke to them and had Shim’on taken away from them, and imprisoned him before their eyes.•before their eyes: As opposed to the sale of Yosef where their presence is not mentioned, strictly speaking.

The man,•The man: Used eight times of Yosef in Chaps. 42–44, perhaps out of ironic anonymity. the lord of the land, spoke roughly with us,
he took us for those that spy on the land!

column3: you will bring down my gray hair in grief
column4: you will bring down my gray hair in grief
column6:
But he said:
My son is not to go down with you!
For his brother is dead,
and he alone is•he alone is left: Of his mother Rahel (see 44:20). left!
Should harm befall him on the journey on which you are going,
you will bring down my gray hair in grief to Sheol!

And they said to Pharaoh:
We have come to sojourn in the land,
for there is no grazing for the flocks that are your servants’,
for the famine is heavy in the land of Canaan.
So-now,
pray let your servants settle in the region of Goshen!

By your father’s God—
may he help you,
and Shaddai,
•Shaddai: Once again connected to fertility (note the content of the following lines). may he bless you:
blessings of the heavens, from above,
blessings of Ocean crouching below,
blessings of breasts and of womb!

There they buried Avraham and Sara his wife,
there they buried Yitzhak and Rivka his wife,
there I buried Le’a—

He said to his people:
Here, the people of the Children of Israel is many-more and mightier [in number] than we!

He said to his daughters:
So-where-is-he?
•So-where-is-he: This is one word in the Hebrew (ve-ayyo). The whole verse stands in ironic contrast to Moshe’s earlier treatment (v. 14) at the hand of “his brothers” (Childs). There, he was rejected; here, his host cannot welcome him quickly enough. Why, then, have you left the man behind?
Call him, that he may eat bread!•bread: As often in both the Bible and other cultures, “bread” is here synonymous with “food.”

column4: with Avraham, with Yitzhak, and with Yaakov
column6:
God hearkened to their moaning;
God called-to-mind his covenant with Avraham, with Yitzhak, and with Yaakov;

And YHWH’S messenger was seen by him
as the flame•in the flame: Others, “as a flame.” of a fire out of the midst of a bush.
He saw:
now here, the bush•bush: Jewish tradition identifies it as a thornbush, but the precise plant remains unknown. The bush, called s’neh in Hebrew, perhaps has the added function here of providing assonance with Sinai. is burning with fire,
but the bush is not consumed!•the bush is burning … the bush is not consumed: The use of tense (plus the opening “here”) conveys the immediacy of the vision.•not consumed: The symbolism of the imperishable bush is left open for the reader; commentators suggest variously Israel and God himself.

Now YHWH said:
I have seen, yes, seen the affliction of my people•the affliction of my people: Heb. ’oni ’ammi.•my people: This fateful designation signals the beginning of the liberation process. The Golden Calf story (Chaps. 32ff.) provides a tragic variation on this phrase. that is in Egypt,
their cry I have heard in the face of their slave-drivers;
indeed, I have known their sufferings!

God said to Moshe:
EHYEH ASHER EHYEH/I will be however I will be.
And he said:
Thus shall you say to the Children of Israel:
EHYEH/I-WILL-BE has sent me to you.

They will hearken to your voice,
and you will come, you and the elders of Israel, to the king of Egypt
and say to him:
YHWH, the God of the Hebrews, has met with us—
so now, pray let us go•pray let us go: Interestingly, the initial request made of Pharaoh is not for emancipation but for permission to observe a religious festival. It eventually becomes clear that Israel cannot be Israel until it is free of Egyptian hegemony. a three days’ journey into the wilderness
and let us sacrifice to YHWH our God!

Pharaoh said:
Who is YHWH, that I should hearken to his voice to send Israel free?
I do not know YHWH,
•I do not know Yhwh: Colloquially, “I care not a whit for Yhwh!” To Pharaoh’s pointed challenge, the entire narrative that follows is an answer (cf. 14:4, 18). moreover, Israel I will not send free!

The king of Egypt said to them:
Why, Moshe and Aharon,
would you let the people loose from their tasks?
Go back to your burdens!

so-now, go, serve;
no straw will be given to you,
and the full-measure in bricks you must give back!

God spoke to Moshe,
he said to him:
I am YHWH.

Pharaoh too called for the wise men and for the sorcerers,
that they too, the magicians of Egypt, should do thus with their occult-arts,

YHWH said to Moshe:
Pharaoh’s heart is heavy-with-stubbornness—he refuses to send the people free.

Plead with YHWH,
for too much is the God-thunder and this hail!
Let me send you free—do not continue staying here!

and in order that you may recount in the hearing of your child and of your child’s child
how I have dealt-wantonly with Egypt,
and my signs, which I have placed upon them—
that you may know that I am YHWH.

YHWH said to Moshe:
Stretch out your hand toward the heavens,
and let there be darkness over the land of Egypt,
so that one will feel darkness!

But against all the Children of Israel, not a dog shall wag its tongue, against either man or beast,
in order that you may know that YHWH makes a distinction between Egypt and Israel.

Let this month be for you the beginning of months,
the beginning-one let it be•Let this … be … let it be: The rhetoric helps to focus attention on this important section. for you of the months of the year.

It shall be for you in safekeeping, until the fourteenth day•fourteenth day: Close to the full moon. of this month,
and they are to slaughter it—the entire assembly of the community of Israel—between•between the setting-times: At twilight. This time is mentioned elsewhere (e.g., 16:12; 29:39, 41; and several places in Numbers) in connection with the sacrifices made by the priests. This perhaps implies that we have here the unusual situation (at least in ancient Israel) of the head of the household performing a priestly function. the setting-times.

And keep the [Festival of] Matzot!
For on this same day
I have brought out your forces from the land of Egypt.
Keep this day throughout your generations as a law for the ages.

It was at the end of thirty years and four hundred years,
it was on that same day:
all of YHWH’S forces went out from the land of Egypt.

Now when a sojourner sojourns with you, and would make the Passover-meal to YHWH,
every male with him must be circumcised, then he may come near to make it, and will be [regarded] as a native of the land.
But any foreskinned-man is not to eat of it.

Moshe said to the people:
Keep this day in mind,
on which you went out from Egypt, from a house of serfs,
for by strength of hand YHWH brought you out from here:
no fermentation is to be eaten.

you are to transfer every breacher of a womb to YHWH, every breacher, offspring of a beast that belongs to you;
the males are for YHWH.

Every breacher of a donkey•a donkey: Not one of the “pure” animals fit for sacrifice, and hence its substitution (“redeeming”) by a lamb. you are to redeem•firstborn of men … redeem: In this case the male child is symbolically transferred to God; child sacrifice was of course abhorrent to the Bible (see Gen. 22). To this day religious Jews “redeem” their firstborn sons with money given to charity, thirty days after birth (Pidyon Ha-Ben). with a lamb;
if you do not redeem [it], you are to break-its-neck.
And every firstborn of men, among your sons, you are to redeem.

Now it was, when Pharaoh had sent the people free,
that God did not lead them by way•way: Some take this to be a proper noun or name: “The Way/Road of the Land of the Philistines.” of the land of the Philistines,•land of the Philistines: That is, along the Mediterranean coast. though it is nearer,
for God said [to himself]:
Lest the people regret it, when they see war,
and return to Egypt!

Now YHWH was going before•going before them: Others, “went before them.” The Hebrew idiom here means “to lead,” especially in war, and is the classic biblical description of a king. them,
by day as a column of cloud,•column of cloud: Heb. ‘ammud’ anan. to lead them the way,
by night as a column of fire,•cloud … fire: These are seen as physical manifestations of God’s presence, and are brought back in the narrative at Sinai (19:16, 18). to give light to them,
to [be able to] go by day and by night.

He had his chariot harnessed,
while his fighting-people he took with him,

Then sang Moshe and the Children of Israel
this song to YHWH,
they said, saying:
I will sing to YHWH,
for he has triumphed,•triumphed: A rendering based on Ugaritic. yes, triumphed,
the horse and its charioteer he flung into the sea!

Who is like you among the gods,•among the gods: The sea is the scene of O YHWH?
Who is like you, majestic among the holy-ones,
Feared-One of praises, Doer of Wonders?

column5: For-what. Notice how the text equates quarreling with Moshe and testing <small>YHWH</small>.
column6:
The people quarreled with Moshe, they said:
Give us water, that we may drink!
Moshe said to them:
Why do you quarrel•quarrel: A verb that often denotes a legal case in biblical texts. with me?
Why do you test YHWH?

YHWH said to Moshe:
Write this as a memorial in a record
and put it in Yehoshua’s hearing:
Yes, I will wipe out, wipe out the memory•wipe out the memory: The command demonstrates the depth of Israel’s animosity toward Amalek. of Amalek from under the heavens!

but you—you are to have the vision [to select]•the vision (to select): The verb “see” in Hebrew (ra’oh) also has the connotation of “select” (cf. Gen. 22:8). from all the people men of value, holding God in awe,
men of truth, hating gain;
you should set [them] over them
as chiefs of thousands, chiefs of hundreds, chiefs of fifties, and chiefs of tens,

so that they may render judgment for the people at all times.
So shall it be:
every great matter they shall bring before you,
but every small matter they shall judge by themselves.
Make [it] light upon you, and let them bear [it] with you.

Moshe chose men of value from all Israel;
he placed them as heads over the people,
as chiefs of thousands, chiefs of hundreds, chiefs of fifties, and chiefs of tens.

You are not to take up
the name of YHWH your God for emptiness,
for YHWH will not clear anyone
who takes up his name for emptiness.•take up … for emptiness: Use for a false purpose. The traditional translation, “take in vain,” limits its scope unnecessarily.

An altar of earth you•you: Here, second personal singular, as well as through v. 23. are to make for me;
you are to sacrifice upon it
your offerings-up, your shalom-offerings,
your sheep and your oxen!
At every place
where I cause my name to be recalled
I will come to you
and bless you.

He that strikes a man, so that he dies,
is to be put to death, yes, death.

nonetheless, if for a day or two-days he endures,
it is not to be avenged, for he is his own “silver.”

God you are not to insult,
and a leader among your people you are not to curse.

At three points in the year
are all your males to be seen
before the presence of the Lord, YHWH.

column3: a rim of gold all around
column6:
Yet against the Pillars of the Children of Israel, he did not send forth his hand;
they beheld Godhood
and ate and drank.

the Glory of YHWH took up dwelling on Mount Sinai.
The cloud covered it for six days,
and he called to Moshe on the seventh day from amidst the cloud.

And the sight of the Glory of YHWH
was like a consuming fire
on top of the mountain
in the eyes of the Children of Israel.

Moshe came into the midst of the cloud
and he went up the mountain.
And Moshe was on the mountain
for forty days and forty nights.

You are to place the two stones on the shoulder-pieces of the efod,
as stones of reminder for the Children of Israel.
And Aharon is to bear their names before the presence of YHWH
on his two shoulders,
for reminder.

You are to make the robe for the efod
completely of blue-violet.

And YHWH said to Moshe:
I see this people—
and here, it is a hard necked people!

Why
should the Egyptians [be able to] say, yes, say:
With evil intent he brought them out,
to kill them in the mountains,
to destroy them from the face of the earth?
Turn away from your flaming anger,
repent of the evil•the evil: Destruction. The biblical use of “evil” (ra’) corresponds more closely to our idea of “ill” as in “ill-fortune”; it includes not only immorality but also disasters that befall people. [intended] against your people!

Moshe saw the people: that it had gotten loose,
for Aharon had let it loose for whispering•for whispering: A derisive kind of whispering. among their foes,

He said to them:
Thus says YHWH, the God of Israel:
Put everyone his sword on his thigh,
proceed and go back-and-forth from gate to gate in the camp,
and kill
everyone his brother, everyone his neighbor, everyone his relative!

So now—
if I have, pray, found favor in your eyes,
pray let me know•know: Intimately. your ways,
that I may [truly] know you,
in order that I may find favor in your eyes:
see,
indeed, this nation is your people!
Hastily Moshe did homage on the ground, and bowed low,

column4: six hundred thousand and three thousand and five hundred and fifty
column6:
a beka/split-piece per capita, the half of a shekel by the Holy-Shrine shekel,
for every one who went through the counting,
from the age of twenty years and upward,
for the six hundred thousand and three thousand and five hundred and fifty.

Then were beat out sheets of gold
and they were split into threads,
to make-use-of-them amid the blue-violet, amid the purple, amid the worm scarlet and amid the twisted byssus,
[all] of designer’s making.

if the Anointed Priest•Anointed Priest: The High Priest. should sin, to the guilt of the people,
he is to bring near, for the sin that he has sinned,
a bull, a young of the herd, wholly-sound, for YHWH as a hattat/decontamination-offering.•hattat: Cf. “On Translating Leviticus,” above. It should be pronounced “hahtaht.”

A person—when one sins and breaks-faith, yes, faith against YHWH:
he denies his fellow’s [charges] regarding a deposit, or what is placed in one’s hand [for safekeeping], or robbery,
or withholds [property] from his fellow;

Command Aharon and his sons, saying:
This is the Instruction [regarding] the offering-up—
that is what goes-up on the blazing-hearth on the altar all night, until daybreak,
•until daybreak: Since everything of the offering-up had to be burned (Bamberger). while the fire of the altar is kept blazing on it:

Thus shall the priest anointed in his stead, from [among] his sons, make it,
a law for the ages, for YHWH:
completely it is to be turned into smoke.

and it was slaughtered.
Moshe took the blood
and put it on the horns of the altar, all around, with his finger, and [thus] decontaminated the altar;
while the blood he poured out at the foundation of the altar.
So he made-it-holy, for effecting-purgation upon it.

Speak to the Children of Israel, saying:
A woman—when she produces-seed•produces-seed: According to ancient belief, women “produce-seed” which is fertilized by the male “seed.” and bears a male,
she remains-tamei for seven days;
like the days of her infirmity of discharge she shall remain-tamei;

Now a cloth:
when there is on it an affliction of tzaraat,
on a cloth of wool or a cloth of linen,

Then the priest is to command that they slaughter the one bird
in an earthen vessel, [held] above living water,

Then he is to sprinkle [it] over the one-to-be-purified of tzaraat seven times, and declare-him-pure,
and is to send out the live bird into the open field.

And it shall be for you a law for the ages:
in the seventh month, on the tenth of the month,
you are to afflict your•afflict your selves: Virtually all commentators (and Jewish tradition) interpret this as a reference to fasting. selves;
any-kind of work you are not to do—
[both] the native and the sojourner that sojourns in your midst.

and to the entrance of the Tent of Appointment does not bring it,
to bring it near as a near-offering to YHWH before the Dwelling of YHWH:
blood is to be reckoned to that man, blood has he shed;
that man is to be cut off from amid his kinspeople—•cut off from amid his kinspeople: Schwartz (1987) understands this as premature death (dying before one’s normally allotted time); Frymer-Kensky (1983) as dying without heirs. Greenstein, on the other hand, shows that it indicates execution, not by human beings, but by some kind of divine agency—perhaps as punishment “for transgressions that escape human detection” (personal communication).

Any-man, any-man—to any blood-relation of one’s [own] flesh you are not to come-near, exposing their•exposing their “nakedness”: To have sexual contact with them; “nakedness” is probably a euphemism for “genitals.” “nakedness”!
I am YHWH!

Do not turn-your-faces to ghosts, of all-knowing ones do not inquire, to become tamei through them;
I am YHWH your God!

You are to hallow the year, the fiftieth year,
and proclaim freedom throughout the land and to all its inhabitants;
•proclaiming freedom … inhabitants: These words were used on the Liberty Bell in Philadelphia, in the form: “Proclaim liberty….” it shall be Homebringing•Homebringing: So B-R and cognates in Akkadian and Ugaritic. Most interpreters understand the word yovel as “ram,” and by extension its horn, but the root seems to indicate “bringing in” of the sheep through horn blowing (cf. Josh. 6:5 for the full term “horn of homebringing”). It usually appears in English as “Jubilee,” a transcription of the Hebrew word. The Septuagint and several medieval commentators interpret it as “release,” which would make it parallel to the meaning of shemitta in Deut. 15. for you:
you are to return, each-man to his holding,
each-man to his clan you are to return.

you may sow the eighth year[’s yield], but you must eat of the old produce until the ninth year;
until its produce comes in, you must eat what-is-old.

But the land is not to be sold in-harness, for the land is mine—
for you are sojourners and resident-settlers with me;
throughout all the land of your holdings, you are to allow for redemption of the land.

If it is not redeemed before a whole year of it has been fulfilled,
the house that is in the town that has a wall shall be established, in-harness, for him who purchases it, throughout his generations;
it is not to go-free in the Homebringing-Year.

You may keep-them-as-an-inheritance for your children after you,
for [them to] possess as holdings;
for the ages you may make them serve you.
But among your brothers, the Children of Israel, each one toward his brother,
you are not to dominate him with crushing-labor!

I will wipe out your sanctuaries and and cut down your cult-stands,
•high-places … cult-stands: Pagan shrines. I will place your corpses atop the corpses of your Illicit-Things
and I will repel you.

These are the [ones] called-by the community,
•called-by the community: The “elect.” the exalted-leaders of the tribes of their fathers;
heads of the divisions•divisions: Heb. elef may have that alternative meaning (mentioned above) here. of Israel are they.

column4: six hundred thousand and three thousand and five hundred and fifty
column6:
thus they were, all those accounted for:
six hundred thousand and three thousand and five hundred and fifty.

When the Dwelling moves on, the Levites are to take it down,
and when the Dwelling is encamped, the Levites are to set it up;
the outsider who comes near is to be put to death!

Bring near the tribe of Levi,
and have it stand [regularly] in the presence of Aharon the priest,
that they may attend upon•attend upon: Or “assist,” “minister to,” “serve.” him.

the hangings of the courtyard,
the screen of the entrance to the courtyard which is about the Dwelling
and about the altar, all around,
and its cords—including all their serving tasks.

and a rush•rush: Others, “fit.” of zealous-rage comes over him,
and he feels rage toward his wife, she having made-herself-tamei;
or rush of zealous-rage comes over him

then the priest is to have the woman swear the oath-curse,
and the priest is to say to the woman:
May YHWH make you a curse and a cause-for-oath amid your kinspeople,
when YHWH makes your thigh fall and your belly swell;

The priest is to make one as a hattat/decontamination-offering, and one as an offering-up;
he is to effect-purgation for one,
in that one became-contaminated•became-contaminated: Alternatively (or simultaneously), “incurred-sin.” by the [dead] person.
One is to make one’s head holy [again] on that day,

column3: you shall be for us as eyes
column4: you shall be as eyes for us
column6:
He said:
Pray do not leave us,
for after all, you know our [best place to] encamp in the wilderness,
you shall be as eyes for us!

Then YHWH spoke to Moshe:
Gather to me seventy•seventy: An inclusive number, indicating completeness or perfection. men of the elders of Israel,
of whom you know that they are elders of the people and its officers;
and take them to the Tent of Appointment
and station them there with you.

Now two men remained in the camp:
the name of the one was Eldad,
the name of the second, Medad,
and the spirit rested upon them
—they were among those recorded,
but they had not gone out to the Tent—
and they ranted-like-prophets in the camp.

The people arose all that day and all night, and all the morrow day
and gathered the quail;
the least gathered ten homers.
They spread them, spread them out,•spread them out: In order to dry them. One ancient version has Heb. sh-h-t, “slew” (them) for sh-t-h, which appears in standard texts. all around the camp.

But Moshe said to YHWH:
When they hear, the Egyptians,
that you brought up this people with your power from its midst,

and make a fire-offering to YHWH:
an offering-up or a sacrifice,
to make a vow-offering, or in free-will, or at your appointed-times,
to make a soothing savor•a soothing savor: A description attached to many sacrifices; cf. Lev. 1:9. for YHWH,
from the herd or from the flock,

Now if you should err,
not doing any of these commandments
•these commandments: Some, such as Milgrom, take this to refer to the two previous sections in the chapter; however, the wording, especially in v.23, is quite broad, and may constitute a new “teaching” about observance of the law (although not a law in and of itself) (Toeg, quoted in Fishbane 1988). about which YHWH spoke to Moshe,

for the word of YHWH they have despised, and his commandment they have violated;
cut off, cut off shall that person be—
their iniquity is on them!

They assembled against Moshe and against Aharon
and said•They assembled … and said: Strangely, Korah himself is never portrayed in the text as uttering a single word on his own—an interesting model for a rebel. to them:
Too much is yours!
For the entire community, the entirety-of-them, are holy,
and in their midst is YHWH!
Why then do you exalt yourselves•exalt yourselves: Or “act-as-leaders.” over the assembly of YHWH?

This, do:
take yourselves fire-pans,
Korah and his entire community,

Speak to El’azar son of Aharon the priest,
that he may set aside the pans from the burned-remains,
and the fire-coals, scatter yonder,
for they have become holy;

Now those that died in the plague were fourteen thousand and seven hundred,
aside from those that died in the matter of Korah.

And also your brothers, the stock of Levi, the tribe of your father, bring near with you;
they are to be joined to you and are to act-as-attendants for you,
you and your sons along with you
in front of the Tent of the Testimony.

And anyone who touches, on the [open] field,
one slain by the sword or a dead-body,
or human bones or a burial-place,
shall be tamei for seven days.

Therefore the bards say:
Come to Heshbon! Be built up;
be established, Sihon’s town!

But YHWH’S messenger stood in the furrow of the vineyards,
a fence on this-side and a fence on this-side.

Bil’am said:
Because you have dealt-wantonly with me!
If a sword had been in my hand,
by now I would have killed you!

Then YHWH uncovered Bil’am’s eyes
and he saw YHWH’S messenger stationed in the way,
his sword drawn in his hand;
he did homage and bowed low, to his nostrils.

Bil’am said to Balak:
Station yourself beside your offering-up, and I will go:
perhaps YHWH will encounter•perhaps … encounter: Note the chance aspect of Bil’am’s contact with God. me in an encounter,
the word of whatever he lets me see, I will report to you.
So he went off by himself.

utters the hearer of Godly sayings
who envisages a vision of Shaddai,
•Shaddai: A name for God (or gods) found mainly in Genesis and Job. fallen, but with eyes uncovered:

They crouch, they lie down like a lion,
like the king-of-beasts: who will [dare] rouse him?
Those who bless you—-blessed,
those who curse you—cursed!

There came near the daughters of Tzelofhad
son of Heyfer son of Gil’ad son of Makhir son of Menashe,
of the clan of Menashe son of Yosef;
and these are the names of his daughters:
Mahla,•Mahla etc.: Several of these names are the names of known towns. No’a, Hogla, Milka and Tirtza.

Here, they were [the cause] for the Children of Israel following the word of Bil’am,
of breaking-faith with YHWH, in the matter of Pe’or,
so that a plague came against the community of YHWH!

column5: Or "high-places.” Pagan cultic Dead Sea. sites situated on the tops of hills.
column6:
you are to dispossess all the settled-folk of the land from before you.
You are to destroy all their figured-objects,
all their molten•molten: That is, cast in metal, like the infamous Golden Calf in Ex. 32. images you are to destroy,
all their sanctuaries you are to wipe out,

column5: spines ... sides ... harrass: Heb. tzeninim .. . tziddeikhem ... tzararu.
column6:
But if you do not dispossess the settled-folk of the land from before you,
those who are left of them shall be
as barbs in your eyes, and as spines in your sides;
they will harrass you on the land that you are settling in,

The inheritance of the Children of Israel is not to go round from tribe to tribe;
indeed, each one to the inheritance of his father’s tribe is to cleave, [among] the Children of Israel.
eleven days [it is] from Horev,•Horev: Another biblical name for Mount Sinai. by the route of Mount Se’ir, [going] by Kadesh-Barne’a.

Face about, march on
and come to the Amorite highlands and to all its dwellers
in the Plains,•the Plains: The Jordan Valley. the Highlands and the Lowlands,•Lowlands: The area west of the hill-country and east of the coastal plain. the Negev/Parched-Land•Negev: The southern region (south of Beersheba). and the shore of the Sea,
the land of the Canaanite and the•the Lebanon: Usually including the definite article in the Bible, as here, this is approximately the region of modern Lebanon, a mountain range extending about 100 miles north of the land of Israel. Lebanon,
as far as the Great River, the river Euphrates.

They took in their hand some of the fruit of the land and brought [it] down to us
and returned us word; they said:
Good is the land that YHWH our God is giving us!

And I commanded you at that time, saying:
YHWH your God has given you this land to possess;
[you] specially-drafted•specially-drafted: Or “hand-picked.” JPS, “shock troops.” [men] are to cross over before their brothers, the Children of Israel, all valiant ones.

You are to bear-in-mind the whole route that YHWH had you go
these forty years in the wilderness,
in order to afflict you, by testing you,
to know what was in your heart, whether you would keep his commandments, or not.

So he afflicted you and made you hungry,
and had you eat the mahn
•mahn: Trad. “manna,” a vegetable substance that according to Ex. 16:14–15 sustained the Israelites in the wilderness. which you had not known and which your fathers had not known,
in order to make you know
that not by bread alone•not by bread alone etc.: Trad. “Man does not live by bread alone.” do humans stay alive,
but rather by all that issues from YHWH’S mouth do humans stay alive.

[At] three points in the year
are all your male-folk to be seen
at the presence of YHWH your God
in the place that he chooses:
on the Festival of Matzot,
on the Festival of Weeks,
and on the Festival of Huts,
and no one is to be seen at the presence of YHWH empty-handed;

And it shall be,
when the officials finish speaking to the people,
the commanders of the armed-forces are to count the fighting-people by head.
You are not to seek their peace or their good, all your days, for the ages!

how he encountered you on the way
and attacked-your-tail—all the beaten-down ones at your rear—
while you [were] weary and faint,
and [thus] he did not stand-in-awe of God.

And YHWH has declared you today, to be for him a specially-treasured people,
as he promised you,
to be careful [regarding] all his commandments,

Cursed be
one striking down his neighbor in secret!
And all the people are to say: Amen!

And it shall be:
as YHWH once delighted in you
by doing good for you and by making-you-many,
thus will YHWH delight in you
by causing you to perish and by wiping you out,
and you shall be pulled up•pulled up: An idiom for “deport,” as in Akkadian (Weinfeld 1972a). from the land that you are entering to possess.

you saw their Detestable Things and their Illicit Things,
of wood and stone, of silver and of gold, that were with them—

I would have said: I will cleave-them-in-pieces,
I will make their memory cease from mortals,

For not like their rock is our Rock,
though our enemies•though our enemies …: Heb. difficult. [so] assess it;
indeed, from the vine of Sedom is their vine,
